How me goes to Luskan?
Would it be possible to hire help here?
Do you think there might be cult activity here?
Me hires help, maybe?
You no think cult here?
What will you be doing while I'm searching for the cult?
How is Aribeth? Has she been well?
How does Aribeth fare?
I believe I have found some information on the cult.
What is the situation in Neverwinter?
I have questions about the region.
I'll be going.
What you do while me searches for cult?
How Aribeth? She okays?
Aribeth is good?
I thinks me have information on cult.
How goes stuff in Neverwinter?
Me has questions abouts region.
Me go now.
How do I get inside the tower?
I have the seal that you need.
Where do I find this Host Tower?
What do you know about the Arcane Brotherhood?
Where me find Host Tower?
What you knows 'bout Arcane Brotherhood?
How me get insides tower?
Me has seal you wants.
What?! What happened?
Do you have any idea where she might be?
So what? What do I care?
I shall try to find her, if I can.
What?! What happen?
You have ideas where she be?
So? Me no care.
Me try finds her.
I'll go now.
Me go now.
How did you become a spymaster for Lord Nasher?
How you be spymasters for Lord Nasher?
You told me to ask you sometime how you met Lord Nasher.
You say me shoulds ask how you meet Lord Nasher.
You had mentioned someone named Calli...
Me remembers you say name Calli...
Now you seem uncomfortable around me. Why is that?
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> I'd still like to hear the tale.
What do you mean? What could be so complicated about it?
I'll ask you another time, then.
Fine. I really don't care, anyway.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Me want to hear story.
What you mean? Why is so complicated?
Me ask later.
Is okay. Me no cares, anyway.
I didn't mean to take this path, but here I am.
I have always had a talent for what I do.
I suppose it was fate.
It seemed like a good idea at the time.
Me not mean to takes path, but here me is.
Me has great talent, me very good.
Me guesses it was fate.
It seem like good idea at time.
I trust you taught him a lesson.
You were a child. What could you have done?
That's horrible!
Me trust you teaches him good lesson.
You small child. You coulds do nothing.
Is horrible!
You murdered him? How could you?
Good. He deserved it.
What happened to you then?
You murders him? How coulds you?
Good. He deserve.
What happen then?
I have heard of him. He was a notorious pirate.
I think so. You became a pirate?
No, never heard of him.
Me hears of him. He big pirate man.
Me thinks so. You was pirate?
No, me no hears of him.
You kept a vicious pirate alive?
Sounds like a good living.
How did you feel, being a pirate?
You keeps bad pirate alive?
It sound likes good life.
How you feel, you be pirate and all?
Thank you for telling me.
I want to hear more!
That's it? Bah! What a stupid tale!
Thank the gods it's finally over!
Me say thanks for telling story.
Me wants to hear more!
Is it? Bah! Was stupid story!
Me thank gods is finally over!
No, I truly want to hear it.
If you do, I'll let you know.
Maybe I'll ask you later, then.
Of course it's boring... but I figure why not?
No, me really wants to hear.
If me bored, me lets you know.
Maybe me ask later.
Yeah, me's bored... but me think why not?
So he captured you?
So you left Randall the Red then?
How long ago was that? You can't be that old.
I have a hard time picturing Lord Nasher doing that.
So he capture you?
So you leaves Randall then?
Was how long ago? You nots old.
Me no picture Lord Nasher doing that.
You betrayed your friend?! What kind of man are you?!
I suppose you did what you thought you had to do.
That was incredibly stupid of you.
That was a very brave thing to do.
You betrays friend?! What kinds of man is you?!
Me guesses you dids what you thinks you had to do.
It was very dumb thing to do.
It was very braves thing, you did.
I wouldn't have betrayed him, that much I know.
I would have left, if I were you.
I don't know. I'm not you.
Probably not, I suppose.
Me would no betray, me knows that.
Me would leave, if me were you.
Me not know. Me not you.
Me guess not.
How did he respond to that?
What he say to that?
You... you're a prisoner, then?
Lord Nasher sounds like a fine man.
But you could have just left, if you wanted to.
You... you is prisoner?
Lord Nasher seem like good man.
But you coulds leave, if you wants.
What's wrong, Aarin?
Calli? Is that a woman?
Good grief, we haven't stumbled upon some sorry secret, have we?
Bah. You're not going to start crying, are you?
What wrong?
Calli? Is woman?
We stumbles on some stupid secret, yeah?
Bah! You nots cry now, me hopes.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Why? What happened?
Perhaps it's best if I not pry, then.
Good enough. I don't really want to know.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Why you do that? What happen?
Maybe is better if me not pry.
Is good. Me no want to know.
Don't tell me... you fell in love.
So did you capture her?
Sounds like one of those impossible romances.
No tell me... you falls in love.
So you captures her?
It sound likes impossible love.
So you captured her then?
This is a very boring story.
And what? She knew you had been there all along?
So you captures her then?
This very boring.
And what? She knows you there whole time?
You killed her?
You kills her?
But of course you didn't.
How did she react?
And you killed her? How could you?!
But of course you not do it.
And how she takes it?
You kills her? How could you?!
That is very sad. I'm sorry.
That's the love of your life? A woman you seduced and assassinated?
I can't believe you did that. How callous and selfish!
Why did you do it?
Is very sad. Me is sorry.
That love of you life? Woman you kill?
Me no believe you do that. How bad and selfish!
Why you do that?
Actually, I agree with what you did... and I am sorry.
I... understand.
No, I can't understand.
Me agree with what you did... and me sorry.
Me... understands.
No, me no understand.
Certainly. I'd like that.
I don't know, Aarin. Perhaps.
Sorry, Aarin. I'm not interested.
But you still look uncomfortable.
Go on, out with it.
Ha! Actually, I like you better this way.
You needn't fear: I will always return.
Don't be so foolish.
You fear for me? That is sweet of you.
Don't make me gag. What are you getting at?
Thank you, Aarin. I shall keep it safe.
I... don't know what to say...
No. I don't want it.
Hail, friend. You were instrumental in ridding Neverwinter of the Wailing Death, I understand. Allow me to congratulate you on a job well done.
You have shown yourself to be possessed of remarkable courage and resourcefulness. That is fortuitous, for both these qualities will be needed if you are to complete your mission.
But that is not how we should begin. I am known as Aarin Gend, and I have served our Lord Nasher for some time. Hopefully I may be of similar use to you now.
You have not spoken to Aribeth, then? Perhaps it would be better if you did so, and then returned to me, for I have much that I need to tell you of.
Indeed. I know who you are. There are many who whisper your name right now, and it is my business to listen to them all.
My place lies in the shadows. I have many eyes and ears throughout the northern lands, and it is my place to inform Lord Nasher where the vipers lay in wait.
If only I had foreseen the actions of this cult, I could have prevented the disaster. But these men move skillfully, out of my sight and hearing.

Instead of recriminating myself for my failure, I must do what I can to repair the damage... and that is to offer what information I have to you so that you may find where this new nest of vipers hides.
You have spoken to the paladin, then? Excellent. It is for her to pass on the commands of Lord Nasher and not I.
I have much to pass onto you, friend... but first you should speak to our lady Aribeth. Once you have done so, return to me.
So impatient to get on with business? You are obviously a <man/woman> of action and are a courageous warrior. Only one such person is needed to change the world.
Aribeth has informed you of where you must search, yes? She has told you of how you may root out these fiends?
Many of Lord Nasher's forces make haste to restore order to the city we have left. Neverwinter's chaos is obvious, and there are many predators in the hungry north.
It falls to us, then... to you... to track down the location of the cult which was responsible for starting this disease in the first place.
We know precious little of them. We do not know who they are, where they are based, why they began the plague... or what other devilry they have yet planned for us.
Unearthing the cult will not be a simple task. What few whispers I have collected, however, have allowed me to narrow your search to this region.

It is vital that the cult's exact location be found, and that we are certain any leads we discover are not attempts at deception. Aribeth will not be satisfied until we find at least two separate leads that point to the same locale... that is your task.
I do know of one possible lead for you. There has been strange news regarding a series of caves that lie north of Port Llast. Investigation may reveal the cult to be hidden there.
I suggest, however, that looking into the caves first would still be your wisest choice.
Impatient for the kill, are we? Just be wary, friend. Running forward too fast is a good way to find a cliff.
Have you more questions, friend? I shall aid you all I can.
The gods smile on us that you remain yet unharmed for your efforts. With luck, success shall soon follow.
Greetings, my dear friend. The presence of such a charming woman as yourself is always welcome. How may I serve?
We are fortunate that you have found the location of this cult, hiding amongst the wizards of Luskan's Host Tower. It is now clear how they possess so much power and stealth.
It is my understanding that you were of immense aid to the druid, Aawill, and indeed the entire Neverwinter Wood. Well done, my friend.
A little bird has informed me that someone has actually won Mutamin's little contest. Such a person must be mighty and clever, indeed, don't you agree?
Even though Luskan is sealed to outsiders, I hear whispers that you have gained admittance. Be most cautious in traveling its perilous streets, my friend.
It... is good to see you at last, my friend. I fear I have terrible news. It seems that the good lady Aribeth... has disappeared. We can find no trace of her.

Aye, a city of pirates and base villainy. The city itself will be closed to you now... but it will be worth your while to go in that direction anyway. You should seek out the humanoid caves by the Green Griffon.
One of the deepest and most ancient woods of the north, my friend. It is filled with life both beautiful and dangerous, and is tended to by the order of druids.
The road leads eventually home to Neverwinter... but before that lay many miles of wildlands as well as the village of Charwood. The cult could hide in many places, there.
There are locals who could tell you more of this town, my friend... my knowledge of it is limited.
Aye? What would you have of me, <FirstName>?
May the luck of the gods be yours, my friend.
Aye, I shall hope that the gods keep you safe, my friend.
I shall await your return, then. Be safe, <FirstName>, and godspeed.

The road north will lead you along the coast and directly to the city's gates. As I said. getting into the city will be more of a problem than reaching it. I will attempt to remedy that as soon as possible.
It is known as the City of Sails, home to pirates and far worse ilk, and ruled by five High Captains who maintain an uneasy balance of power.
True power, however, lies in the hands of the mages of the Arcane Brotherhood within the Host Tower. Even I know little of these men.
The city is powerful, anarchic and dangerous. Luskan has challenged the Lords' Alliance more than once... be careful when you walk its streets, for many within see strangers as easy prey.
Evil men are common as coins in Luskan, my friend. This cult could walk the streets unnoticed, and find many allies who would heed gold above all else.

Additionally, I have been troubled by reports of humanoid banditry taking place on the road between Neverwinter and Luskan. This is unusual... and while it may simply be caused by Luskan's ignorance, it should be investigated.
Follow the road east of Port Llast. The lands are wild and sparsely populated there... and when you reach the boundaries of the great forest, you will know.
Like Neverwinter, the forest is warmed by the magically heated waters of the river that runs through it. It is a grand and beautiful place, I am told.
Few journey through its boundaries, however, as it is said that the wood has a life of its own... and is unwelcoming to outsiders.
The druids of the wood, watched over by the Archdruid Aawill, are aware of all that passes within their charge. It is my hope that they can provide you aid.
The Archdruid Aawill has sent several letters to Lord Nasher as of late, begging for aid against some unknown force that assails the wood.
Lord Nasher would have provided the help the Archdruid required, but could not due to the chaos within the city. Neverwinter must come first.
Aawill has sent no more messages in recent days, and it is possible that the druids exist no more. The exact danger that was being faced was not explained... this cult may not even be involved.
It may, however, so this may be an excellent avenue for you to search. Whatever has occurred, my friend... expect the worst.
The southern road is not so much a place you go to, my friend, as it is a route you take. It will lead you eventually to Neverwinter... but it is the region itself that concerns me.
Very little. There has been little news from the village of Charwood for many years, I understand. It may have been deserted, for all I can tell.
Ruins will be common, and it is said that other, stranger, creatures have made these wildlands their home. A powerful wizard is even said to have taken residence.
I have no reports from this area. None. This disturbs me perhaps more than it should, as the cult could exist openly here and I would not even know.
I offer the South Road as a possibility mostly out of speculation, my friend. I simply would not wish to leave it out entirely... just in case my suspicions have good reason.
The fact that the city remains sealed even now that the plague has ended, and so little word escapes its walls, also has me worried of what events transpire there.
Lady Aribeth has arranged for the hiring of several skilled adventurers. They are here with us... if you require their aid, you need only ask one of them.
I did my best to investigate Port Llast before we made our base here, my friend... but what you suggest is not impossible.
There may have been things ongoing in this place which escaped my notice. An investigation on your part is not without merit.
I still serve as Lord Nasher's master of spies, my friend... and his need for proper information is more vital now than even before.
My ear must remain to the ground, even if my efforts must be co-ordinated from here rather than deeper in the shadows.
I shall continue to seek word on the cult that might aid your quest... though I have my doubts in that. You will have far more success than I, I think.
Let me see what you have. Yes... excellent. I had full confidence in your abilities, my friend. Bring the information to Aribeth quickly... she will be eager to see it.
The noble paladin earns my pity, friend. Her heart has been broken and her faith shaken... I do not think 'well' is a word that will describe her ever again.
I am informed that she has been plagued by terrible nightmares that keep her from rest. She speaks horrid things in her sleep, frightening the servants.
I can only imagine what the elf sees when she closes her eyes. She will not confide in me, nor will she agree to return to Neverwinter. I worry for her, truly.
I... would not normally speak of this, <FirstName>, but I am told that you and the lady paladin have formed a bond of friendship.
Aribeth has stirred from her grief, but not as I'd hoped. She has replaced it with a frightening rage that she almost cannot contain.
She storms about, brooding and filled with bitterness and lashing out at all who come near her. I do not know if anything can even be done... perhaps you could speak to her.
Grim. Lord Nasher reports that many of our armed forces have perished from the plague... and even more are needed to restore order to the city.
The worst is perhaps over now that the plague is cured, but still we reel from a crippling blow. It will be some time before things return to what they were.
What do you wish to know?
The tower lies on an island, reachable by a bridge on the northwestern shore. There are rumors of other entrances... but I have been able to find none.
The bridge, however, is guarded well by both armsman and sorcery. The wizards of the Arcane Brotherhood value their privacy.
Little enough, if the truth be told. The wizards search diligently for spies at every turn, so I receive only questionable news from outside the tower itself.
It is known, however, that the Arcane Brotherhood are the true power in Luskan. The High Captains rule the city, but only with the wizards' leave.
How the cult gained its foothold there can only be guessed at. The wizards may be allies... or, indeed, even members of their cause.
If you do gain entrance, use extreme caution and find out all you can about their plans. Assaulting them directly may not be an option.
I believe I know of a way... though it is a risky path, to say the least. The bridge to the tower's island is guarded by magic that is not easily by-passed.
Those who wish admittance to the tower must be granted the proper pass by the wizards... papers which are affixed with a magical seal that allows the possessor to pass unhindered by the wards.
Unfortunately, the only persons which I am sure possess such a pass are the High Captains, themselves.
If you were somehow to acquire one of these documents for me, with its seal, I could easily use it to forge a similar pass for you.
Excellent work, my friend. I have already managed to put together a forgery that will claim the bearer as an ambassador of Mulhorand.
It is then a simple matter of moving the seal from one document to the other... as so... and it is done.
This forgery, then, should allow you to by-pass any guards at the bridge, as well as the magical wards. Once inside, however, I would not rely on it.
The lady paladin had been quite silent since you left Port Llast. I thought perhaps that she had found contentment now that the cult was located.
So my eye was not as close upon her as it might otherwise have been. Regardless, she used considerable skill to vanish without notice sometime after our arrival in the city.
All of her gear and armor is gone, as well. She prepared well and left of her own volition, though I can scarce believe it.
She has not returned to Neverwinter. Part of me wonders if... if perhaps she seeks to exact her own brand of vengeance upon the cultists.
I cannot be certain. Aribeth was acting so strangely before her disappearance. She had an icy calm, as if the lady paladin had accepted an unpleasant fate.
I worry for her safety. She is not in her right mind, I fear.
As you wish. I am concerned for the lady paladin, even if you are not. I thought at the least you should know.
Your most important task is to find your way into the Host Tower, my friend. The cult must be dealt with. If you find Aribeth there, all the better.
If she is not within the Host Tower, a true search will have to wait until after your own mission is complete, no matter how much we might wish otherwise. So, then... let us discuss your mission.
I shall pray for your success, my dear friend. Be safe, for I could not bear your loss.
That is a curious question, my friend. Nor does it have a simple answer, if the truth be known, and is not a tale that I care to often tell.
Aye, so I did, though I had not expected that you would be truly interested in hearing the rest of the tale. Are you sure I am not boring you?
I... did. That I mentioned her at all was by accident, my friend. I have been determined to avoid those memories for many years, now.
Do I seem uncomfortable to your eyes? I shall amend my stance, then, <FirstName>, for I do not wish you to feel ill at ease.
I can only imagine what the elf sees when she closes her eyes. She will not confide in me, nor will she agree to return to Neverwinter. I worry for her, truly.
She storms about, brooding and filled with bitterness and lashing out at all who come near her. I do not know if anything can even be done... perhaps you could speak to her.
I mean that it is more than one tale. How I became a spymaster is quite different from how I met and came to serve our Lord Nasher.
I am no drunken bard to spill the story of my life at a moment's notice, however, so either story is usually one I keep to myself.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> *Sigh* As you wish, my friend... though I'll not be held responsible should you nod off during the telling of it.
Let me see... perhaps it is best if I ask you a question, first. You are a <man/woman> of your god, <FirstName>, are you not?
Let me see... perhaps it is best if I ask you a question, first. You are a <man/woman> possessed of wondrous magics, <FirstName>, are you not?
Let me see... perhaps it is best if I ask you a question, first. You are a <man/woman> of great skill, are you not?
Let me see... perhaps it is best if I ask you a question, first. You are a <man/woman> of great fighting prowess, <FirstName>, are you not?
Let me see... perhaps it is best if I ask you a question, first. You are a <man/woman> of nature and the wild, <FirstName>, are you not?
How is it that you came into your calling? Was it an accident? Was it born purely of talent? Do you believe you were fated to be what you are?
Aye, and no doubt the same could be said for many. Few know that the path they start upon will lead where it does.
It must be a fine thing to be sure of one's abilities. I envy you that. For most, the destination is never clear until they arrive.
Fate is an odd thing, wouldn't you agree? Crystal clear when behind you, yet evasive and unknowable when before you.
Ha ha! Well spoken, my friend! What is truly best is only known once it is done, is that not the way of it?
I, myself, started life as a slave in the southern deserts of Calimshan. Never would I have foreseen that I might become who I am today.
I knew of the lush and wild jungles of my homeland, Chult, only through the bedtime tales of my mother. I have never laid eyes upon its shore.
My mother was owned by a most vicious and cruel caliph. As a slave child, one learns to stay out of sight and to move silently, lest one be beaten.
Moreover, I learned to listen. I listened to the chatter of the servants, the bored talk of the guards. For many, many years I was the shadow in the caliph's halls.
For all my hiding, however, I proved of no use to anyone but myself. I could not save my mother when the caliph beat her to death for spilling a tankard of his mead, for instance.
Aye, though in truth it was I who learned the lesson. I blamed myself for not warning my mother, for not stopping the caliph's blow.
I blamed myself, regardless, as the young often do.
Aye, but such is the life of a slave. I was the caliph's shadow, however, and I blamed myself for not stopping his blow... young and foolish as I was.
In grief and anger I stabbed and killed the caliph, and was subsequently chased into the streets of Calimport.
I am not proud of what I did, <FirstName>. It is very easy to say that the man deserved it. Deserved it more than my mother did, at the very least.
Who am I to say that this is so, however? I was no righteous judge that day... I acted out of retribution and became a wanted murderer in truth. There is no denying that.
I fled into the shadows of the city... and was not alone, there. I found many who I will call allies and not friends, for we acted in unison only to survive.

The law pursued me, so always I remained hidden and listened as I once had. The fact that I was a thief to remain alive did not help... and eventually even the shadows of the city were no longer safe for me.
I sought passage out of the city... and eventually a captain took pity on me and gave me a position aboard his ship. Perhaps you have heard of Randall the Red?
Aye, that he was... a pirate who's reputation along the Sword Coast was more than deserved. I joined his crew, though I was no pirate in truth.
Randall the Red deserved his reputation as a violent and cunning pirate of the swordcoast. While I joined his crew, I was not a pirate as you think of it.
No? Randall the Red once held quite the reputation as a bloodthirsty pirate of the Sword Coast. I was a member of his crew, though not a pirate as you think of it.
I was not fond of drink as the other sailors were, and instead spent my time at each port making new contacts, and listening.
Over the years, Randall grew to depend on my skill. He gave me gold to establish informants throughout the coast, and I heard news the instant it happened.
It was I who kept Randall safe and one step ahead of his pursuers, for always would I know before the chase was on us.
Aye. I was his master of spies, though I would not have put a name to it at the time. I was grateful for Randall's kindness... for despite his reputation, he was an easy man to like.
I was not truly a pirate. I was his master of spies, though I did not put a name to what I did. And while Randall was indeed a pirate, he was an easy man to like.
I was not fond of the looting and pillaging Randall indulged in... and did my best to subtly steer him away from the worst of it.
Randall knew what I was doing and permitted it only because I was otherwise invaluable to him. He cared not if I cringed and turned a cheek when the crew plied the worst of their bloody trade.
As the years past, I came into a certain amount of my own fame along the Sword Coast. My life was my life, and I was satisfied with it and discharged my duty as best I knew.
It was not until I encountered Lord Nasher that my life would change forever. That, however, is another tale. Ask me of it some time, my friend.
And thank you for listening, <FirstName>. As I said, it is not a tale I tell often.
Ha ha! Perhaps another time, my friend. You made for a fine audience.
I am sorry you think that. Perhaps that is why I do not tell the tale often.
Ha ha! Well, my friend... you did ask.
Ha! Of that I have no doubt.
Is that so? I have not had someone eagerly asking me such since... well, never. Usually I am not so, how shall we say, available?
So be it. You will recall, I hope, that I made the majority of my early fame as the spymaster for the infamous Randall the Red, aye?
That life continued much unabated. Our ship found safe harborage in Luskan, and Randall plagued the Neverwinter trade lines endlessly.
Lord Nasher was not always the aged man you know now. When I first encountered him he was a man in his prime... a veteran of the sword and in possession of a brilliant mind.
Lord Nasher vowed to end Randall's reign over the waterways. He personally sailed from Neverwinter to seek and destroy our ship.
Perhaps. Once, however, Lord Nasher was reknown as the greatest lord of the north. The very idea that he was personally chasing us frightened the crew and gave Randall pause.
I was still a young man at the time, my friend. Our Lord Nasher already had a lifetime of adventure behind him and was the greatest lord of the north.
Of course not. I owed him much, and did not know this Lord Nasher at all. He was, however, the greatest lord of the north... and his personal attention gave Randall pause.
Not at first, no. Lord Nasher was the greatest lord of the North at the time, however, and his personal attention frightened the crew and gave Randall considerable pause.
For two years we sparred, he and I. It was all I could do to discover his ingenious plots to find Randall just in time to avoid them. Never had I labored so.
Once he even disguised himself and his men as Waukeenar priestesses shipping gold to Amn, knowing that would draw Randall like a moth to the flame.
Only at the last moment did I give in to my suspicions and warn Randall from their ship. It was a very close thing, however.
In the end, it was I who betrayed Randall. He grew more desperate and more violent, plundering ships and killing all aboard. This he had never done before.
When next the shadows told me of Lord Nasher's latest plot, I... did nothing. I waited silently and watched as Nasher's men sprung from Randall's latest target.
Randall was no true friend. I owed him much, and had repaid that and more. I had a choice to make, however... would you have done differently?
Randall was no true friend. He made use of me, and I had needed him. It was a choice I had to make, <FirstName>, and it was no easy one.
Truly? I am surprised, then, for I could not do other than what I believed to be right. You and I must be very different people.
I am no longer in the mood for tales, <FirstName>. It is enough for you to know that I came to serve Lord Nasher after that.
I suppose that is all I can expect. I, myself, could not do other than what I believed to be right. It was not an easy choice to make.
I am glad to hear that. It was not a simple choice to make.
I fully expected to be executed, and waited grimly as I was rounded up with the rest of Randall's men. My fate, as I saw it, was sealed.
I waited a long time in the dungeons of Castle Never. The first man who came to my dark prison, however, was none other than Lord Nasher himself.
He was very intense and charismatic... and suspicious. I was, after all, a well-known pirate, yes? He asked me only one question:
"Why did you not warn Randall the Red of my attack?"
I told him that even though I served Randall I could not allow what he was doing to continue. Lord Nasher seemed surprised by my answer.
"So you would betray any man you served if you did not agree with his actions?" he asked me. And I had only one answer.
I said I would betray any man who I felt was wrong, and my only regret was that I had waited as long as I did with Randall.
He smiled at me... and said that he only hoped that if he did something wrong that I would tell him first.
I asked him if this meant I was to serve him now. To that he said no... I was to serve Neverwinter. That was to be my sentence.
I am twenty years into my sentence now, my friend, and I have been thankful for each year of it.
That he is, my friend, that he is. And Neverwinter is a place I love. I could not have found a prison that suited me better.
Not truly, my friend. I have come to admire Lord Nasher and love Neverwinter with all my heart. It is a prison that suits me well.
Perhaps. I am glad I did not, for Lord Nasher is the best of men, and Neverwinter a prison that I have grown to love.
And had I left, I never would have met my Calli... I...
It is not your concern, and I should not have mentioned her. Regardless, my tale is done.
It is... nothing, my friend. Something best forgotten that I... should not have brought up.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> *Sigh* I suppose one cannot leave the story unfinished. As you wish, then, my friend.
Calli is short for Calliara. She was of elven blood, as you are... a woman of extraordinary beauty and adventuresome spirit.
Calli is short for Calliara. She was of elven blood... a woman of extraordinary beauty and adventuresome spirit.
She ran the guild of thieves in Neverwinter, you see, when I first began my sentence. She was also the first task Lord Nasher set me to.
I was to see to her capture, and to reduce the power of the guild in the city... and I was eager enough to do so, though I did not know what I was up against.
Not at all. For quite some time, she and I were the most dire of foes. Calliara stirred her entire guild against me, and assassins stalked my every step.
Not at first. She and I became the most dire of foes. Calliara stirred the guild against me, and assassins stalked my every step.
You joke, although you should know it was no romance at first. Calliara and I were the most dire of enemies, and she stirred her entire guild against me.
The thieves had been used to holding power in the city and did not care to be dislodged. I used every trick I knew to no avail.
Finally I chose to disguise myself and infiltrate her guild, determined to look upon my foe and end her life personally.
It took me a great deal of time to do so. Calliara trusted few, and I had to work my way up in the ranks over time until I was able to enter her inner circle.
No, not at all. I killed her.
Not at first, no. Not until I killed her.
Aye. I should have done it sooner, when I was first trusted enough to be alone in her presence... but I was too intrigued and foolish.
She enthralled me. I found her soul so similar to my own, and we drew together immediately. Despite my misgivings, I gave in and allowed myself to love her.
I knew it would not last. I discovered her plan to kill Lord Nasher, and knew that the time had come to tell her who I was. It was my hope to dissuade her from her life.
No, I didn't. I didn't think I could. She was not angry, as I thought she would be... merely disappointed as she drew her sword.
She was not angry, as I thought she would be. Merely disappointed, perhaps, as she drew her sword.
I had little choice. My heart sank because I knew she would never surrender. She was not angry with me, as I thought she would be... merely disappointed as she drew her sword.
To strike her down was almost unthinkable. As we parried, I begged her to reconsider, to leave her life... to stay with me, and I would protect her from Lord Nasher's wrath.
"I will not change for you, Aarin... even as you would not change for me. Let it end here."
Though tears blurred my eyes, upon those words I ran her through. She died moments later, as we exchanged one... final kiss.
Thank you, <FirstName>. I have... never told another that tale.
I did not expect you to understand. Perhaps I should have known better than to share my tale.
She would not leave, my friend. Nor stop her plans. It was not in her to do so, just as I would not have were our roles reversed. And I could not let her succeed.
Though it broke my heart, my path was clear and fated to be. I must... accept that. Can you understand, my friend, even if you do not agree?
I am glad to have shared it with you. You are an intriguing woman, yourself... I consider myself fortunate to have been assigned to you.
Perhaps in time we might get to know one another better. As... as good friends. Would you... would you care at all for that, <FirstName>?
There are few that I would call friend, <FirstName>. I would be pleased to name you amongst them.
Now you make fun of me. So be it, <FirstName>, I shall speak plainly.
Aye, perhaps I do at that. Perhaps to maintain what dignity I have, then, I should speak plainly.
(sigh) I see you know me too well, now. Very well, then... I shall speak plainly.
I am... not accustomed to dealing closely with others. I am too used to the shadows, remaining unknown and unknowable.
You, however, have forced me to re-examine that part of myself. I... find myself keenly aware of you... of your absence when you leave, and I fear for your safety... I fear that you might not return.
Aye, for you are a marvel of a woman. Powerful, competent and full of courage... easily the equal of any man, and I admire you for it.
Though I need not fear for you. Indeed, you are a marvel of a woman... powerful, competent and full of courage. Easily the equal of any man, and I admire you for it.
But I fear there are still dark times ahead where even your power and courage will be tested.
The shadows about you may become such that you fear you are alone and cannot find your way out of them.

Take this, <FirstName>. It was given to me by my mother long ago, so that she knew I would always find my way out of the shadows. Take it and be reminded that there is one who prays for your safe return.
Then say nothing, <FirstName>. Take it in the spirit with which it is meant.
Aye, I know that you will.
As you wish. Is there something else I could answer?
Then why did you ask? Surely you must have better things to do.
Back to more important matters, is there something you needed?
Of course. What else would you have of me?
I am not here to amuse you, <FirstName>, nor are you here to amuse me. Ask me of something other than myself.
Your original question has been answered, I hope. Let us return to the topic of your mission and... speak no more of me, today.
I appreciate your kindness, <FirstName>. Perhaps another time I will be more willing to speak of it.
Since I do not wish to speak of it, I have no trouble with that.
Then allow me to end it here. You need hear no more, I am sure.
Regardless, let us return to the topic of your mission and speak of me no more.
Perhaps, in time, I might come to hear your tale. For now, however, there is much to do.
I... I see. Please excuse me if I seemed... forward. Perhaps it is best if we turn to another subject, then.
I am pleased. Of course, there is much else that needs to be done. Perhaps we can speak of this another time.
I... nothing, my friend. Please... ignore that I said anything. I have clearly overstepped my bounds. Let us speak of something else.
I... I see. Please forgive me, my friend. Clearly I have overstepped my bounds. Let us... speak of something else.
Let us speak of other things, then... for you have much to do.
What exactly are Lord Nasher's orders?
What be Lord Nasher's orders?
I am more concerned about how you are holding up.
Me more concern about you, not orders.
What do you think I should do now?
What you think me should do?
I have some questions about this mission.
Me has questions about mission.
How are you feeling? This must be a terrible strain.
How you feel? This all big headache, no?
Do you have any advice for me?
You haves advice, maybe?
You want to find this cult badly, do you?
You wants to find cult badly, huh?
I'll go now.
Me go now.
What are you and Aarin Gend going to be doing here while I search?
What you and spymaster doing here while me searches?
How do you propose I look for this cult?
How does I looks for cult?
What should I do if I discover something?
What me do if I finds something out?
Why are we not searching more in Neverwinter?
Why we not searching more in city?
Just what do we know about this cult?
What we knows about cult, anyway?
I want to ask something else.
Me has other question.
I have located some information about the cult.
Me find out stuff about cult.
That sounds like a dangerous task.
Enter tower? It sound mighty dangerous.
Can I expect some help? Will you be coming with me?
Me get help? You coming, too?
How will I get into the tower?
How me get into tower? You know?
I'll do my best.
Me go now, then.
What do you mean? What plans?
What you mean? What you plan?
You look tired. Have you not been sleeping well?
You looks tired. You not sleeps good?
Aarin says you have been having disturbing dreams.
Aarin say you haves bad dreams.
You said I should ask you how you became a paladin.
You say me should ask how you become paladin.
You seem angry. Is something wrong?
You looks angry. Is something wrong?
Aarin mentioned that you've been very short of temper.
Aarin say you very angry all the time.
Everyone can make a mistake, Aribeth, even for the best reasons.
Fenthick was a fool to follow his duty so blindly.
It is very sad, what happened to him. I am sorry for your loss.
Don't be so naive. Not everyone is as caught up in duty and goodness as you are.
Even a paladin has a heart, Aribeth... you can't be the avatar of justice all the time.
I don't really have anything to say about that.
All can makes mistake, even me knows that.
Fenthick was dummy to only see duty.
Yes, is all very sad. Me sorry.
Pfft. You naive. Nobody thinks duty everything like you.
You haves heart, Aribeth... you not be perfect.
Me not haves anything to say 'bout that.
Don't let feelings blind you to the truth about Fenthick, Aribeth.
You feelings is blinding you 'bout Fenthick, Aribeth.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> No, go on. Tell me what you were going to say.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> No, you speak. Tells me what you going to say.
Just make sure this doesn't come up again.
You makes sure this don't come up again, then.
Yes, it is. You should pull yourself together.
No, you're being too hard on yourself, Aribeth.
It is never wrong to question. What's important are your answers.
I can't answer that for you, Aribeth.
Yes. You shoulds get head together.
You be too hard on youself.
Is not wrong to ask. What answer is, is important.
Me cannot answer for you, Miss Aribeth.
No, he didn't.
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> Yes, he did, actually.
No, he no tell me anything.
<StartCheck>[Lie]</Start> Yes, he dids.
No, it's not surprising at all.
These dreams are disturbing enough to keep you from sleep?
What sorts of things do the servants claim you say?
Perhaps you've gone mad. Completely cracked.
No, is no surprise.
Dreams is disturbing and you no sleep?
What servants say you speak in sleep?
Maybe you gone mad, a crazy woman.
You don't sound very convinced.
You no sounds convinced.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Why don't you tell me about these dreams? Maybe it will help.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Why don't you tell me about these dreams? Maybe it will help.
Have you considered that maybe it's more serious than that?
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Tell me 'bout dreams. Maybe it help.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Tell me 'bout dreams. Maybe it help.
You think maybes it more serious?
That's understandable. They would frighten me, as well.
Obviously something is seriously wrong with you.
It is only fears and worries dredged up by your mind, Aribeth.
I don't know what to say about that.
Is okay. Me would be scared, too.
Something big wrong with you, maybe.
It only you mind full of fear and worry, me think.
Me not know what to say.
Perhaps I'm wrong, then. I'm sorry.
Deny it if you wish, Aribeth, it's not natural.
I'm no fool, Aribeth... and neither should you be!
Maybe me wrong. Me sorry.
You say it wrong if you likes... it not normal.
Me no fool. You should no be fool, neither.
No, I want to hear it.
I'll let you know if I get bored, don't worry.
Maybe some other time, then.
No, me wants to hear it.
Me let you know if I gets bored, you no worry.
Okay, me hears later.
That doesn't sound like you at all.
How did you become a paladin after that?
Okay, getting bored now...
That no sound like you.
How you be paladin after that?
Okay, me gettings bored...
Who was the man who saved you?
The man who saved you... that was Tyr?
You're right, this is a long story.
Who man that save you?
Man who save you... is Tyr?
You is right, is long story.
No, I'm only joking.
Yes, maybe I'll hear this later.
No, me just joke.
Yes, me hear later.
What happened then?
You became a cleric, then, like Fenthick?
So you think Tyr, himself, commanded you to worship him?
What happen then?
You becomes cleric? Like Fenthick?
So you thinks Tyr tell you to worships him?
I'm sorry, I didn't mean to sadden you.
So were those dreams like the ones you have now?
You're not going to cry again, are you?
Okay, story over. Let's talk about something else.
Me sorry... not mean to make you sad.
Those dreams like dreams now?
You not goings to cry again, me hope.
Okay, story is done. We talk 'bout something else.
What has changed?
What change?
I do.
I don't need another friend.
Whoa... slow down there, lady!
Does this mean we can go to bed soon?
Me does.
Me need no more friends.
Whoa! You be very forward!
Uhh... this mean we goes to bed soon?
But Fenthick was involved in the deaths of thousands of people!
Perhaps it's Fenthick you should be angry at.
And what should have happened, do you think?
Maybe you should be angry.
I don't like hearing you talk like this.
But Fenthick help kill many people!
Maybe you shoulds be mad at Fenthick.
What you thinks should have happen?
Maybe is okay you are angry.
Me no like hearing you speaks like this.
You sound as if you're losing your faith.
What brought this on, all of a sudden?
Don't talk like that! Stop it, this isn't like you!
Finally I think you're seeing the light!
You sounds like you loses faith.
Why you act like this now?
You no talk like that! This not you!
Finally me thinks you sees the light!
The dreams have gotten worse?
This is bad. Perhaps we should return to Neverwinter.
I think you really may be going mad!
I have almost had enough of your constant angst.
Dreams worse now?
This bad. We shoulds go to Neverwinter.
Me thinks you go mad!
Me have almost enough of you bellyacheing.
I promise.
I can't promise that, Aribeth.
I don't think that will help you.
You are mad!
Me promise.
Me can no promise that!
I no think this helps you, Aribeth.
You is mad!
What do you mean?
Very well, I will take it.
No, I don't want it.
What you mean?
Okay, me take it.
No, me not want it.
It is good to see you here in Port Llast, my friend. If we are to have any luck in tracking down this strange cult behind the plague, it will be with your aid I am sure.
I do not know how much you have been told about Lord Nasher's orders. I shall help you understand whatever I can, certainly.
Perhaps allow me to explain exactly what Lord Nasher wishes of us. Yes, perhaps that would make our path more plain.
You know, of course, that Desther and... and Fenthick... were associated with some manner of religious cult that was behind the Wailing Death in the city.
We know so little about this cult... and it would be foolish in the extreme to suppose that simply because their activities in Neverwinter have been stopped, that they have been defeated.
Lord Nasher commands that we track down the headquarters of this cult, and discover their plans... and stop them, before another atrocity is committed.
Aarin Gend, Lord Nasher's spymaster, is here in Port Llast to help us do this... and has brought reports of many strange activities throughout the northern lands.

It is possible that agents of the cult may be behind some of these activities. If so, we may be able to find them and discover where their base is located. Your aid in this, <FirstName>, will prove invaluable.
How I feel is... unimportant, <FirstName>, next to the mission we have been given. Please, allow me to explain what is required of us.
Of course. Ask what you will of me, <FirstName>.
I am here to see that Lord Nasher's commands are carried out, while Aarin continues to use his network of spies to gain more information beyond Neverwinter's walls.

Admittedly, my own role seems sparse. Part of me thinks that my Lord Nasher simply wishes someone he trusts in this role... while another believes he does not wish to be reminded of Fenthick or my pain.
Regardless, we will do all that we can to help you, <FirstName>. Do not think your efforts go unrecognized.
Aarin has several ideas on places where the cult may be hidden. Currently he is working on finding a way into the city of Luskan... its gates have been sealed since the plague in Neverwinter began.
I suggest you talk to Aarin about where these places might be. Search for any clues about the rise of ancient cults or odd activities. Once a way into Luskan is found, you can search there, as well.
If we are fortunate, you will perhaps encounter some part of the cult and gain information as to who they are and where they are based.
Any information you discover should be brought to Aarin and myself. Once we know more about the cult, Lord Nasher can decide what to do next.
The search does continue within the city, <FirstName>. Indeed, Lord Nasher is having Neverwinter scoured thoroughly for more traces of the cult.
It is his feeling, however, that the true force of the cult lies outside of Neverwinter... and that it is your efforts here that will prove the most valuable.
Desther appears to have been their link in Neverwinter, as you discovered, but of the cult itself we have been able to ascertain little.
Aarin is positive that its true heart lies outside of Neverwinter, and that it has yet to show us the extent of its strength.
The task ahead of us will, no doubt, be most dangerous... but that makes it all the more necessary that we do not remain ignorant of what this cult is and what it intends.
Certainly.
I would suggest you speak to Aarin Gend and find out where to focus your efforts in finding evidence of the cult.
I wish there were better leads we could send you on, <FirstName>, to track down the cult... but Aarin's information is the best we have.
All I can suggest is that you visit the locales Aarin has mentioned and keep your ears open for unusual activities.
Not everything that is unusual will be the doing of this cult, obviously... but they are out there, and active, so there is always a good chance you will discover them if you are alert.
Your information tells us that the cult likely lies within the Host Tower in Luskan. You need to find a way to gain entrance into Luskan and into the tower, itself.
Aarin should be able to help you toward that end. We will both meet you in the city, afterwards, to help you further.
Then I wish you luck, <FirstName>.
As you wish.
Go with Tyr's blessing, then, <FirstName>... and be safe.
Then I wish you well, my friend. Return to me as soon as you can.
You will need to get into Luskan and enter the Host Tower, itself. Speak to Aarin... hopefully he will have some ideas on how you can go about this.
Without a doubt. You have faced tasks of similar danger, however, and excelled... and will no doubt face much worse before this threat is ended.
You did agree to aid Lord Nasher, did you not? Whatever your reasons, I find it hard to believe that you expected this to be very simple.
Both Aarin and I will join you in Luskan, of course. Aarin will be there to help you enter the tower, <FirstName>. As for me, I have... other plans.
I am sorry, but I... cannot tell you, <FirstName>. Please do not ask me to.
My plans are my own. You have your own mission to worry about, <FirstName>.
I wish I could tell you, <FirstName>, but I cannot. I have... little choice in the matter. Please just... do as you are asked to.
Speak to Aarin Gend, as I said. With luck, he will have a plan to not only get you into the city but into the tower, itself.
Very well. Go and speak to Aarin, then. May... Tyr watch your path, <FirstName>. May Tyr watch over us all.
Go, then, and speak to Aarin. I hope that... I wish... no, nevermind. Be safe, <FirstName>.
It is of vital importance that you complete Lord Nasher's mission, <FirstName>. Much depends on you discovering what else Desther's allies have planned.
I am pleased to see that you remain safe, my friend. Lord Nasher tells me he is confident of your success, though I do worry at the danger in which you place yourself.
It is good to see you again, <FirstName>. At times I worry that you have taken on too much responsibility yourself, yet always you surprise me with your resourcefulness and success.
Have you yet discovered any new information on the cult?
We need to gain admittance into Luskan to follow your lead about the Host Tower. Speak to Aarin Gend... he has a plan to get you into the city.
My strain should not surprise you, <FirstName>. My only love lies dead, and while it was my lawful Lord who executed him, his true murderers remain beyond my reach.
Are you a fool to ask me that? My only love lies dead, executed as a traitor, and his true murderers lie completely beyond my reach!
Aye, it is, as I am sure you can well imagine. Fenthick... my only love... dead at the hands of my lawful liege. His true murderers, however, lie invisibly beyond my reach.
Would you not feel the same, <FirstName>? I remained passive while my love was executed, and this wretched cult remains invisible and impervious to my wrath.
Do you believe me without feelings, without a heart? I wish I could descend upon these madmen with all my pain and fury... yet they are invisible and beyond my reach.
You would never understand, I am sure! My heart cries out with the pain of watching my true love murdered, it wishes justice and is denied!
I wish, with such fervor that it frightens me, to see those allies of Desther pay - to see Tyr visit them with terrible justice!
But... perhaps you mean well enough by your question. I apologize if I have misjudged your intent.
I am a paladin of Tyr, sworn to uphold good and justice... yet somehow I cannot condemn Fenthick in my heart. He meant only to do what he saw was his duty, I am sure of it.
Aye, a mistake... but it is more than that, isn't it? Fenthick was hanged for treason, disgraced in the eyes of his lord and his god.
Harsh words, but... but perhaps there is a ring of truth to them. It was Fenthick's own dedication that led to his downfall.
A fool, you say? What do you know of him? You judge him like all the others have judged him, without stopping to consider what was truly in his heart!
I... thank you, <FirstName>. That is kind of you to say. My own loss seems insignificant, however, compared to Fenthick's disgrace.
Naive, am I? I am a paladin, <FirstName>, and my duty is part of who I am, not some trivial preoccupation!
I would expect that you, above all others, would be aware of that. I would have hoped that you would not judge Fenthick like all the others have.
But of course you do not understand me any better than Fenthick, so you judge him just like all the others have!
But of course I should expect such a response from someone of your creed. How could I expect you to understand me, nevermind Fenthick?
But as a paladin I am supposed to hold myself above such earthly concerns. I am supposed to know my path and be sure of it... just as Fenthick did. Or thought he did.
Is it I who am blind, <FirstName>? If I am, to which truth am I blind about? Fenthick was hanged for treason, but I know there was no treason in his heart.
I am not blinded, <FirstName>. If anything, my eyes have been opened. You judge Fenthick just as everyone else has.
No, of course not. Nor would I expect you to. Please forgive me, <FirstName>... I have a duty of my own to attend to, and I should remain focussed on it.
It... ah, but I should not be distracting you from your task, <FirstName>. My own problems are unimportant and of no interest to you, I am sure. Please forgive me.
If what's in our hearts does not matter, then what happened to Fenthick could happen to anyone... you, me, anyone.
Then all our time spent dedicating ourselves to... ahhh, this gets me nowhere. There are far more important events to attend to than my own ills.
Let us return to the matter at hand, <FirstName>... namely, your task. That is far more important and I will not distract you from it further.
Then I will be sure not to. Let us return to the topic of your task, then.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> It... it is just that Fenthick's fate could have been mine. Or yours. Or anyone's. How do you know that the path you walk is the correct one?
I have never questioned my faith or my duty before. But neither did Fenthick. I feel... doubt, <FirstName>, and I am ashamed to admit it.
Perhaps I am merely wallowing in my sorrow, perhaps I know my path better than I think I do, but I am no longer sure. Is it wrong for me to think such thoughts?
Yes, I... I suppose you are correct, <FirstName>, this is getting me nowhere. I should put these questions out of my mind for the time being.
Am I? All my training and instincts as a paladin tell me I am not being hard enough. Perhaps it is best if I put these thoughts out of my mind, for now.
Yet I have no answers, only more questions. (sigh) Thank you for allowing me to unburden my heart, but perhaps it is best if I put these thoughts out of my head, for now.
No, I suppose not. It is something I must think on... but not now. It is best if I put these thoughts out of my head for the time being.
The safety of Neverwinter relies on your mission, and my duty regarding that is more than clear. Let us speak of that, instead.
Why do you ask me that, <FirstName>? The spymaster put you up to this, didn't he?
I see. I suppose my state is obvious enough. Aarin is far more concerned than is warranted, however... certainly a few bad dreams are not a reason to become alarmed.
Aarin is a dear man, but I find his concern over my lack of sleep to be somewhat unnecessary. Surely a few dreams are nothing to be alarmed of.
The servants claim I speak in my sleep and say frightening things. They creep about me cautiously like I have gone mad, and Aarin pays their superstitious twitterings far more heed than he should.
After all that has happened with the plague and... and Fenthick, I think a disturbing dream or two is not so surprising, wouldn't you agree, <FirstName>?
Finally, someone with some sense! I keep telling Aarin that these strange dreams are nothing to be concerned over, but he insists on treating me like an invalid.
These dreams shall... they shall pass, in time. There are far more important matters to worry over than how I am sleeping.
Gone mad, have I? Some restless nights caused by more sorrow than my heart can bear and suddenly I am some raving harpy to be handled with padded gloves?
I should have known better than to discuss such a matter with you. Let us return to the topic of your mission and speak of this no more.
The dreams are simply dreams, no doubt caused by more sorrow than my heart can bear. I will not discuss them... especially not with you.
Let us return to the topic of your mission, <FirstName>, and speak of this no more.
Now you, too? Has the world gone mad, or is it me? These dreams are... disturbing and frightening, but... they shall pass! They are my burden to bear and no one else's.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> *Sigh* Perhaps you are right, <FirstName>. Having the perspective of another on these dreams may not be a bad idea.
These dreams are... strange. I'll grant you that. But these are not exactly normal times for me, either.

I... I am falling, in the dream. Always falling. Surrounded by a heavy blackness which chokes and drowns me. Grasping hands reach out to me, and the voices... a cacophony of whispers that plead to me for help.
And... and then I see a shrouded figure. It is Fenthick. He is walking away from me and I run to catch him, but always he eludes me in the darkness.

The voices get so much louder. They are accusing me, blaming me, and I... I feel ashamed, though I do not know what I am being blamed for. I cry out for help, for them to stop their assault, but I go unheeded.
And then I catch up to the figure... and I see that it is not Fenthick. He turns and gazes at me with sad eyes... and I know it is Tyr... and then my god turns his back on me.
These... these are my dreams, <FirstName>. Perhaps now you can understand why I have not wished to discuss them. I am... frightened... of what they may mean.
That's kind of you to say, <FirstName>. I am glad I told you, at least... it makes the dreams seem a bit smaller, now.
I do feel better for it, thank you. Hah... I am reminded, a little, of how I was introduced to the paladin life. You should ask me to tell you the tale, sometime.
Until then, however, let's return to the subject of your task. That is something we can focus on, at least.
It's all right, <FirstName>. There isn't much that can be said, is there? But... I am glad I told you. It makes the dreams seem a bit smaller, somehow.
Such as? I am going mad? Or I am under the influence of evil magic, perhaps? Don't tell me you subscribe to the same superstitious prattle as the servants!
No... I'm sorry, <FirstName>. I should not be so... quick to find my temper. I do want you to be honest, and it is good to talk about the dreams, at least.
I think you are over-reacting... but I do want you to be honest. Perhaps I should consider what you say. It does feel better to talk about the dreams, at least.
I deny nothing. But I do feel sorry for having discussed this in the first place. Let us return to the topic of your mission and not speak of my dreams again.
If I'm a fool, it is only for discussing my dreams with you in the first place! Let us return to the topic of your mission and not speak of this further.
I did say that, didn't I? Are you sure you wish to hear the tale? It is not an exciting one, and I would not wish to bore you, <FirstName>.
That would probably be best. What can I do for you, then?
Ha ha! Of that, I somehow have little doubt. All right then, <FirstName>... if you truly want to hear my tale, then I shall tell it.
As you wish. Do not complain later, however, if you find the tale does not live up to your expectations. I am, after all, no bard.
Where should I begin? My family lived in a human village in the wildlands of the northern mountains, and I once longed for nothing more than to be a skilled hunter, as my father was.
The village was destroyed when the orcs massed and attacked the southlands. My family was killed, though I survived.
For years, I thought of little but wreaking bloody vengeance upon the orcs. I stalked the crags with my bow, mercilessly killing all I crossed.
Indeed, I was much different then. My vengeance consumed me, and I dealt death at every turn... but I had no peace.
It was not an easy thing. My lust for vengeance consumed me. I was no better than the beasts I hunted, to be truthful.
Shush, <FirstName>. I have barely begun my tale. Control your attention span for a moment.
On the fifth winter of my hunt, I stalked an orc tribe deep into the Spine of the World and encountered a blizzard so terrible I could do naught but camp and pray.
The blizzard was merciless and lasted days, and as I lay dying in the snow and wind I spotted a human man approaching. I thought I was mad.
He was tall and strong, though I noticed he was missing his right hand. The cold did not seem to affect him... and he looked down at me kindly and picked me up from the snow without effort.
I remember nothing beyond that. When I awoke, I found myself at a small Ilmateri monastery near the city of Silverymoon. The monks told me I had nearly died.
I have often thought that he was none other than an avatar of Tyr, himself, the Lord of Justice. Though perhaps that is persumptuous of me.
I have often thought him thus. An avatar of the Maimed God, himself. Though perhaps that is presumptuous of me.
(sigh) You did ask to hear this, <FirstName>. Do you want me to stop?
Very funny. Perhaps I am just not in the mood for levity. Let me return to the topic of the man who saved me.
Whoever he was, the Ilmateri monks had not seen him bring me... and I never saw him again. Or perhaps I should say I never saw him in person.
He came to me time and time again in my dreams for many months afterwards, telling me that my vengeance would bring no true justice.
I refused him at first, determined to return to my bloody hunt. The dreams came more frequently, and the man grew more stern with me.
The path lay elsewhere, I was told, and reluctantly I left the mountains and came to Neverwinter and entered the service of Tyr. The dreams never came again.
Not right away. I did not meet Fenthick until later, in fact.
I do not know. I did not worship him at all, at first. I was resentful of the dreams and bitter over giving up my hunt of the orcs.
Tyr's clerics took me in and over time I learned their ways and grew to admire the Maimed God. I chose to champion justice instead as his paladin, and found peace at long last.
My dedication saw me rise through the ranks, and it was much later that I encountered the young acolyte, Fenthick, and knew that I... had found... my true path at last...
No. No... I am done with crying.
Aye. Let us... talk about something else.
No. No, they are not alike at all. The dreams in the mountains never frightened me as much. They didn't make me feel so helpless and alone.
I only compare the current ones to them because they are so strong, and disturb me so profoundly. I feel as if... something has changed. Something has changed inside of me.
No, I... thank you, <FirstName>. Thank you for listening to my tale. You have been a great comfort to me.
I do not know. Not yet. But... I thank you, <FirstName>, for listening to my tale. You have been a great comfort.
Let us talk of something else.
I... am glad that you have come to work for Lord Nasher. You have so many admirable qualities, he could not be better served.
I am glad to call you a friend, and hope that we can remain thus in the future. For now, however, perhaps our attention should return to your mission.
I would be glad to call you a... a friend, <FirstName>. Tyr only knows that finding a friend in times like these is difficult enough. I hope you feel the same.
I... I see. That is too bad, then, for a true friend is a grand thing to have. Let us return to the topic of your mission, then.
Oh, I meant no... no disrespect! I was suggesting only... that is, I only was... oh, do not mind me, <FirstName>. Let us forget I said anything, please.
... I shall forget you said that, sir. Perhaps we should forget that I said anything, either.
I am glad, my friend. Let us return to the subject of your mission, then.
Aye, I am angry. I have been thinking more and more of how Fenthick met his end... and how I did nothing to stop it... and I grow even more angry!
Fenthick devoted his entire life to the service of justice and the performance of his duty, just as I have. And what did he get for it?
Discarded. Discarded by his liege lord to appease the witless masses, discarded by his god for one foolish mistake. Tell me why I shouldn't be angry, <FirstName>!
You make him sound like a murderer! It was not Fenthick who created the plague, nor Fenthick that betrayed the city! He was merely too trusting and too devoted to duty!
Aye. Fenthick deserves plenty of my ire, as well. The stupid, stupid fool! If only he had been less trusting, less devoted, he never would have ended as he did!
What should have happened? Perhaps he should have received some recognition of his long service and his good intentions! Or perhaps he should have been less trusting and more selfish!
Aye. I should be angry at those who condemned Fenthick for the wrong reasons. I should be angry at Fenthick, too, for being a good man and a trusting fool!
And why shouldn't I talk like this? If Fenthick had questioned more and been less trusting, less devoted, perhaps he would be alive today!
And so Fenthick got his final reward. Thank you, Tyr, Lord of Justice, for aiding your faithful servant! Shall I be next, then?
Shall I, too, end my life a traitor, executed for being too adhered to my duty to question an injustice when I see it? Will Tyr abandon me then, too?
I... I don't know, <FirstName>. Tyr brought me here, put me on this path. I want to know why. Why teach me true justice and then throw it in my face?
And what *is* like me, <FirstName>? Tyr brought me to this place and put me on this path and taught me the meaning of justice... only to throw it in my face. I want to know why!
I have had no revelation... only questions upon questions. Tyr put me on this path, taught me true justice... only to throw it in my face. I want to know why!
All I know is that... I am tired of being sad. I am tired of feeling helpless. I feel guilty for questioning myself... but I feel I must be questioned.
Vengeance is not Tyr's way, but I... I fear I see no justice being done, here. There is no justice to be had for Fenthick, only vengeance... and I cannot do it.
Perhaps it is just... the dreams. They continue to come, and get worse each night, <FirstName>. I hear voices crying out, so many voices...
Aye. I see Fenthick killed before me, over and over. I hear laughter, and so many crying out to me for help. I almost cannot bear it.
No. No, there is nothing for me there. And doing so would only hinder your mission... and I will not do that.
Perhaps I am, at that. I can think of only one thing that would soothe my thoughts.
And I thought you were a friend. I see that no one understands what I am going through... aye, so be it.
Leave me be, then, <FirstName>, and return to your mission. We need discuss my feelings no further.
Promise me, <FirstName>... promise me as my dearest friend that you will find this cult and visit upon them the vengeance that I cannot!
I see. It is all I can think of that will silence the dreams. Perhaps... perhaps you are right. Perhaps all I need is some rest to put this into proper perspective.
Thank you, my friend. It... it is all I can think of to silence the dreams. I must do something, and to have you help me brings me great relief.
You have been a fine friend, <FirstName>. Here... take this. It is a ring that belonged to my father. I want you to have it.
Let it symbolize our friendship. Perhaps if... something were to happen to me... it would remind you of me in days to come...
Then throw it away, if our friendship means nothing to you. I hope that is not the case.
I don't mean anything, my friend. It is... simply fatigue and worry that make me speak such. Please... take the ring.
That makes me glad. You do me a great honor by carrying it.
Let us speak more later. Go, <FirstName>... find where the heart of this cult resides and return to me. I wish you luck with all my heart.
Please listen, I have some very important information for you.
When was he here?
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> What kind of equipment did he carry?
Did he leave a name?
What was he? Human? Dwarf?
Thanks for telling me.
When he talk to you?
He have name?
What he be? Human? Dwarf?
Yuh? Okay, me go now.
Be calm! What are you talking about?
Explain. Me not know what you mean.
Oh my, you're the one! You must be! You look just as the horrible beast said!

Listen to me! Just a short time ago, someone came here looking for you or, at least, someone who matches your exact description. He said he was going to slaughter you and he demanded to know where you were. Nearly slit my throat, too!
He wore some heavy, spike-covered armor and carried a massive sword in his scabbard. It was the biggest I've ever seen! He had murder in his eyes!
Yesterday. I could barely sleep last night for thinking about it. Gods, I nearly died!
No, no name. Just said he was with the cult... none of us had the courage to ask any questions... there was dried blood on his hands!
He was some sort of orc and a huge one at that!
It was the least I could do. I suggest you run away and never return! I think I might!
There is a monster looking for you, <sir/madam>! A beast! He's going to kill you! Oh, gods, he almost killed ME!
I must be leaving now.
Did your friend give him any info?
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> How did he kill your friend? Magic?
I'm sorry my presence has brought such suffering...
Is there anything I can do to repay your loss?
All right, I'd better clear out before anyone else gets hurt.
Your buddy tell 'im 'bout me?
Me bring this upon you. Me sorry.
Can me help at all?
Okay, me go before anybody else gets hurt.
Here, take 600 gold.
Here, take 400 gold.
Here, take 200 gold.
Guess I don't have anything to spare.
<StartCheck>[Threaten]</Start> Forget the funeral. I'm confiscating all you've got...
Yuh? Okay, take 600 gold.
Yuh? Okay, take 400 gold.
Yuh? Okay, take 200 gold.
Sorry, me no have enough right now.
<StartCheck>[Threaten]</Start> Forget funeral. Me put money to better use.
Yuh, you in *big* trouble...
There was big fellow in here, lookin' for someone exactly like ya. Pretty sure it's ya. Buddy of mine tells 'im to get lost an' da big guy kill him for it! Bled all over...
No, split 'im right in half with this big jagged-lookin' blade.
Me buddy didn'a but after I saws 'im all split in 'alf like dat, I tells da guy you been 'round dese parts... I dare any man 'ere to say 'e wouldn'a done the same thing right then!
Yuh? Well... thanks, eh? Me always told me buddy that that mout' of 'is would be the death o' 'im. Least 'e did it for a good <man/woman>.
We was gonna hold a big funeral for 'im. We figures he's a hero for standin' up like that agains' the cult. A li'l donation to that would be nice...
Yuh. These be troubled times 'bout these parts.
Really? Yuh, this go a long way. We'll have big hero's funeral for 'im.
Yuh? All right but don' you forget about 'im, okay? 'E gave 'is life to protect you, yuh?
Damn adventurers! Make you drink yer buddy's blood, then cough up an' pay fer more! Here, 400 gold. It's all I 'ad to bury 'im with.
Damn adventurers! Make you drink yer buddy's blood, then cough up an' pay fer more! Well you and yer friends 'ave already robbed me broke an' blind!
I leave now.
Looks like your bait has borne fruit after all, Jaheel. Quick, close in on them.
Where did you encounter him?
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> Do you have any advice for facing him?
